3.66.text: G'day, my name is Josh Jensen. I'm a marine biologist and the underwater cameraman

10.03.text: I filmed the "Nature's Aquarium" series, and I'm going to talk you through some of what's

13.80.text: going on in the underwater scenes of this film. "Oceans" is basically a collection

18.84.text: of some of our favourite seascapes from the countries we visited and filmed over the past five years.

24.44.text: I think it's a privilege to be able to dive

26.83.text: and see what's under that big blue blanket, and I think that privilege

30.57.text: gives all divers an obligation to document that beauty to share with others if we can.

34.84.text: Our oceans are in serious trouble, and it's only through an awareness

40.72.text: that we can learn to use marine resources sustainably.

49.10.text: You can probably see that the current is running pretty hard in this shot:

52.21.text: the red sea whips are bent over, the fish are swimming pretty hard but not really going anywhere.

56.62.text: Current can be challenging, but it brings rewards.

59.80.text: In fact, pretty much the whole coral reef system—and in fact the entire marine world—

64.33.text: relies on currents, and specifically the plankton that the current brings with it.

68.18.text: Plankton is any organism that gets moved around more by the current

72.34.text: than by its own propulsion. There are literally millions

75.97.text: of tiny planktonic organisms flowing through this scene every second.

79.70.text: All those particles you can see, and even more way too small to see.

83.84.text: Plankton is what turns the water from crystal clear

87.02.text: into the maybe 30m/100ft visibility that you can see in this shot.

92.56.text: Some plankton are tiny things, smaller than bacteria, that get filtered by sponges;

97.17.text: next up in size are the single-celled plants called phytoplankton,

101.34.text: which might get filtered or eaten by microscopic animals called  zooplankton;

106.30.text: and all those zooplankton are eaten by small fish, which are eaten by the bigger fish.

111.30.text: Think of coral reefs as massive filters.

114.54.text: I'll often talk about plankton predators called planktivores.

118.20.text: Throughout the film, I'll also refer to a lot of critters as filter feeders,

121.62.text: and it is plankton that they are filtering and feeding on.

129.83.text: This is a typical remote Indonesian coral reef.

134.74.text: The school of small orange fish are one of the most common and conspicuous species of planktivores you'll find.

140.84.text: They're called Scalefin anthias, and these are all females.

145.12.text: For every 20 or so orange females, you'll see a mostly purple male,

151.26.text: and the male usually swims just above his harem, every now and then you'll see them

155.49.text: make frantic runs up and down as a display to the females and to rival males.

171.78.text: Each hard coral is actually a colony of hundreds to millions of tiny animals called polyps.

178.18.text: They're called reef building corals because their stony skeleton

181.92.text: creates habitat for the incredible diversity of reef fish.

186.23.text: Each fish has evolved to fill a specific niche created by the diverse coral growth forms.

194.74.text: and there are at least six different species in there—

198.22.text: they shelter amongst this staghorn coral during the day...

201.57.text: and at night they'll move up into the water column to feed,

204.63.text: and the daytime planktivores will move down into the staghorn coral to sleep.

216.17.text: Most species canʼt survive alone. This anemone, for example,

219.66.text: is in a mutualistic symbiotic relationship with clownfish—

222.79.text: that means both species benefit from the partnership.

225.90.text: The clownish defends the anemone from butterflyfish attack,

229.16.text: and the clownfish get a safe place to live and lay their eggs.

232.90.text: Itʼs a really well-studied and well-understood field...

235.93.text: but there are strange things going on in this shot:

240.24.text: thatʼs the single grey fish here—they arenʼt normally associated with anemones,

244.49.text: but this guy is most likely waiting to be cleaned. There are usually cleaner shrimp on anemones,

249.12.text: but itʼs probably the juvenile Blunthead wrasse—those are the black and white ones—

253.25.text: or the juvenile cleaner wrasse that will dance in shortly—

256.31.text: that will do the cleaning in this particular station.

259.07.text: Whatʼs extra unusual about this shot is the Sixstripe wrasse—the little pink and green fish swimming throughout the tentacles—

265.00.text: heʼs not supposed to be able to do that without getting stung and eaten.

274.32.text: There are hundreds of species of animals that we never see—

277.34.text: mostly worms, but also crustaceans and molluscs—that live

284.36.text: If you were to slice down into that coral rock youʼd find it looks like Swiss cheese: lots of holes in it.

289.96.text: The big fella feeding here is a Titan triggerfish

292.57.text: and he is biting off chunks of that rock with incredibly strong teeth and

296.44.text: powerful jaws to find big juicy worms that he knows live inside.

302.01.text: But in searching for those big worms, he is also exposing lots of smaller worms and other critters,

306.54.text: and thatʼs food for all the other fish species you can see here.

310.13.text: Thereʼs a Moorish idol, a pair of Pacific double-saddled butterflyfish,

314.16.text: a Checkerboard wrasse... there will also be smaller wrasse and hawkfish hanging around looking for scraps, too.

319.92.text: Titan triggerfish almost always have an entourage of these

323.70.text: opportunists which are attracted to the scene by the crunching sound of coral being broken.
